title: Jenn Deng's Exploration with LLMs
text:
---
title: "AI & Love"
description: "Falling in love... with a robot?"
author: "Jenn Deng"
date: "2/28/2024"
categories:
  - LLMs
  - prompting
---

title: AI Hallucinations
text:
Hallucinations in AI happens when there are incorrect or misleading results generated by AI models. This happens when an AI system makes false assumptions or uses biased data to generate information. > How do hallucinations happen? > * not enough training data > * biased training data > * wrong assumptions > * processing errors
Sometimes, there‚Äôs wrong code or images that pop up. It‚Äôs up to us to choose whether the information is right or wrong. Let‚Äôs look at a few examples that a few people have encountered in the past.




I took a quick look on Reddit to dig for some examples of ChatGPT hallucinations. I wanted to see if they still existed, since some of the posts were 1-2 years ago.



 Jenn‚Äôs update: Well, I think they fixed this up. 



Ok, well‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs check on Reddit for some more ChatGPT hallucinations



 Jenn‚Äôs update: It‚Äôs interesting how they try to reference the information, but still got the information wrong. 



Ah-HAH! One down. Let‚Äôs try another one. Now, I‚Äôm not an organic chemistry person, but let‚Äôs see if this one has updated from 2 years ago.



 Jenn‚Äôs update: Well, darn! This is sad for any organic chemistry lovers out there. ChatGPT is really bad at organic chemistry.

title: Guestimation and Making Graphs in R!
text:
Guestimation and Making Graphs in R

I also want to learn how to code more in R, and I really like graphs
I‚Äôm going to ask ChatGPT if they can give me code to make graphs.
These questions will be guestimations on what ChatGPT thinks of certain trend lines.


Let‚Äôs cook.

1. Years Lived vs Amount of Friends

Jenn asks: Can you create R code for a graph to show your guestimation on years lived vs amount of friends.


ChatGPT:
 


When I asked why there was this trend, ChatGPT responded with > The trend I used in the R code is based on general social patterns observed in human friendships over a lifetime. Here‚Äôs why I shaped it that way: >1. Friendships Peak in Young Adulthood (20s-30s) People tend to have the most friends in their teens and 20s, especially in school, university, or early careers. Social environments like college, sports, clubs, and workplaces provide many opportunities for new friendships. There‚Äôs generally more free time for social activities before major life commitments (e.g., demanding careers, marriage, parenting). >2. Gradual Decline in Middle Age (30s-50s) In the 30s and 40s, people often prioritize careers, families, and personal responsibilities, leading to less time for socializing. Some friendships naturally fade due to geographical moves, lifestyle changes, or shifting priorities. However, a smaller core group of close friends often remains. >3. Further Decline in Older Age (60s-80s) Retirement, health issues, and the loss of peers contribute to fewer active friendships. Many elderly people rely more on family, close lifelong friends, or community groups rather than maintaining large social circles. Some older adults reconnect with old friends or develop new friendships in retirement communities, but the overall trend is downward. > Why This Trend Makes Sense? Social networks are largest in early adulthood when we have high social mobility and opportunity. Life responsibilities impact time and effort spent on friendships as we grow older. Aging naturally reduces social engagement, with some maintaining strong bonds but a smaller total number of friends. Of course, this is a generalization‚Äîindividual experiences vary widely! Some people maintain or even expand their social circles in later years. Would you like me to adjust the model to include different factors, such as personality types or social media influence?
And honestly, I think their prediction and trend line is correct. Let us move on‚Ä¶



2. Age vs Breast Cancer Rates

Jenn asks: and can you write code for age vs breast cancer rates > ChatGPT: > >  > 
When I ask why they think it exhibits this trend: > Why This Trend? > Young women (20-30s): Very low breast cancer rates. Middle age (40-50s): Rates begin to rise due to hormonal and genetic factors. Older age (60-80s): Highest incidence rates, as risk accumulates over time. This is a simplified model based on general trends seen in epidemiology. Would you like a more specific model with real-world data, or adjustments to include factors like genetic risk?

title: Valentines Day Poems
text:
Love in the Age of AI: Can Machines Understand Romantic Poems?

Current AI systems cannot have emotions in the sense that humans do‚Ä¶ but are they able to detect and analyze human emotion? 
While they can be programmed to recognized and respond to human emotions, they can simulate emotional responses without truly feeling them 
I want to see if AI is able to read love poems and analyze them to the extent that human beings analyze them. Let‚Äôs get started! 


‚ÄúOn Fighting Transience‚Äù was a sweet poem written for me, and I never understood what it really meant

Jenn: There is a love poem called ‚ÄúOn Fighting Transience‚Äù, what does this title mean to you?


ChatGPT:  The title ‚ÄúOn Fighting Transience‚Äù suggests a struggle against impermanence‚Äîperhaps an attempt to hold onto something fleeting, like love, beauty, or life itself. It evokes a deeply romantic and philosophical idea: the desire to resist the inevitable passage of time and the loss that comes with it. In the context of a love poem, it could explore themes like:  Eternal love despite the impermanence of life.  Cherishing moments before they slip away.  Memory and longing‚Äîtrying to preserve a love that has passed.  Defying fate‚Äîresisting change, distance, or even death in the name of love.  It feels like a perfect theme for Valentine‚Äôs Day‚Äîan ode to the enduring nature of love, even in the face of time‚Äôs relentless march.


Jenn: Here is the poem, please tell me what it means and how you analyze it 


On Fighting Transience  My favorite authors create from memory,  write odes and odysseys sparked by recollection,  scrape the walls of their skulls prodding poetry to life.  You do the same, subtly  showering me with stories of family til tears line your face,  soft sobbing like slow plucks of violin strings,  turning tension to beauty and I want to cherish  this moment for a little while longer.  Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,  waves and fogs from trying to retain everything I‚Äôve ever done,  replacing older memories with something new, less worthless,  recreating poetry and prosody in this room‚Äôs low light,  I‚Äôll start here ‚Äî  holding your hand as we push chess pieces across the board,  overworking gray matter while you disregard strategy,  and I watch you smile at each loss.  Nixing squares of black and white,  mixing pain and pleasure as we succumb to headaches and heart pains,  soon subsumed by pasts that flow off tongues like river water,  puddle in the air before invisible boundaries,  collide against secret dreams till we‚Äôre both still.  Your head pressed against mine, sincerely silent  because words won‚Äôt do this moment justice.  Sitting on the floor, learning to share the air for several seconds,  pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising  things will be better tomorrow, or maybe the day after,  or maybe next week, and soon I forget  because truly I lost track of time  the moment you entered my arms, that first handshake,  then hug, making us both fools, fate-bound,  spinning round and round in revolutions I won‚Äôt recover from,  so I embrace this chess-laden dance, drink in the sweetness of your humor,  recalling the moment we first met,  me, tongue-tied and stupid,  and you, asking if I wanted to take a picture,  asking if I wanted that moment to last. 


ChatGPT: Analysis of On Fighting Transience

This poem is a deeply emotional meditation on memory, love, and the struggle against impermanence. It explores the ways in which we try to hold onto moments, people, and feelings, despite time‚Äôs inevitable passing.
Theme 1: Memory as a Tool for Fighting Time
The poem begins with a reflection on how authors and poets create from memory, turning recollections into lasting art. The speaker admires this ability, yet seems to struggle with their own attempts to do the same. There‚Äôs an urgency in the lines:

Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,
waves and fogs from trying to retain everything I‚Äôve ever done,

This suggests a fear of forgetting, a frantic attempt to preserve experiences before they slip away.
Theme 2: Love and the Desire to Hold Onto Moments
The heart of the poem is a love story intertwined with nostalgia. The speaker describes intimate moments with their partner‚Äîplaying chess, sharing laughter, feeling the weight of past pain. There‚Äôs a sense of trying to freeze time, particularly in lines like:

I want to cherish this moment for a little while longer.
Pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising things will be better tomorrow‚Ä¶

This highlights the contrast between what we wish to be permanent (love, connection, laughter) and what inevitably fades (memories, pain, even people).
Theme 3: Love as an Anchor in Time‚Äôs Revolutions
The closing lines bring the poem full circle. The speaker reminisces about their first meeting, recalling how their partner asked:

if I wanted to take a picture,
asking if I wanted that moment to last.

This suggests that from the very beginning, there was an awareness of time‚Äôs fleeting nature‚Äîthat love and connection are temporary, but we still seek to make them last, even if only in memory.
Symbolism and Imagery - Chess: A symbol of strategy, time, and careful planning. The partner disregards strategy, suggesting they live in the moment, whereas the speaker overthinks. - Water (waves, fog, river water): Symbolizes memory and time‚Äôs fluidity‚Äîit flows, puddles, disappears, and cannot be fully contained. - Hand-holding and physical closeness: Represent a desire for permanence, for grounding oneself in the present moment despite the inevitable passing of time.
Final Thoughts
This poem beautifully captures the human struggle against transience‚Äîthe attempt to preserve fleeting moments through memory, love, and poetry itself. It suggests that while we can‚Äôt truly stop time, we can hold onto the essence of moments through connection, storytelling, and remembrance.
Would you like to incorporate these themes into your blog post? This poem ties in perfectly with Valentine‚Äôs Day because it speaks to love‚Äôs impermanence and the desire to make moments last.



Analysis of ChatGPT‚Äôs Analysis

I think that ChatGPT was able to do a pretty accurate analysis of the poem, however, it really dives into the symobolism and imagery way more over the way a human would describe the emotion of the poem in their understanding.



But Can GenerativeAI Write Poems That Are Similar to This?

Let‚Äôs find out.

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage
from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI


# Initialize the ChatOpenAI model
model = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-4-turbo")  # Ensure you set the correct model

# System message defining role
poemMsg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are a poet who specializes in love poems.'''
)

# Human input to request a poem
human_msg = HumanMessage("Write one with the title 'On Fighting Transience' and make it revolve around someone you're falling in love with.")

# Invoke the AI model with system and human messages
poemResponse = model.invoke([poemMsg, human_msg])

# Print the generated poem
print("Here's the poem:", poemResponse.content)

Here's the poem: **On Fighting Transience**

In the whispering twilight of our budding days,
Where shadows dance and the light softly plays,
There you stand, a silhouette against time‚Äôs tide,
Each fleeting moment urging us to decide.

In your eyes, a constellation, rare and bright,
Guiding me through the quiet cloaks of night;
Your laugh‚Äîa melody, serene and clear,
That captures time, making it adhere.

Yet whispers of transience, persistent and cold,
Speak of warmth turning weary, and whispers growing old;
They tell a tale as ancient as the stars above,
Of time‚Äôs cruel jest and the fragility of love.

But we, with hands clasped and spirits entwined,
Challenge quiet storms and the fates unkind;
For though roses wilt and rivers do wane,
Our ardor blooms, a defiant refrain.

We stitch our moments with threads of gold,
Each kiss a story, vividly told;
With every touch, a promise we impart,
To stand guard over the beats of our tender hearts.

For love, though besieged by temporal decay,
Grows roots in souls and will not easily sway;
In defiance of time‚Äôs relentless flow,
We carve a haven where transient things don‚Äôt go.

In your presence, the rush of time loses its breath,
And the fear of an ending is put to rest;
Together, we summon the strength to oppose,
Turning moments to eternity‚Äîwhere true love forever glows.




Analysis of GenAI Poem
While it‚Äôs not as personalized as the human written poem, the language of the poem is still beautiful.  It‚Äôs interesting to see how the poem is about a girl, I was interested to see what gender they would assign to the lover.  The poem is really structured, as therer are 7 stanzas all having four lines.  I think this could pass off as a human written poem, though it sounds more old-style than the casual and informal poems we see today.



Conclusion
GenAI can write a good poem if you give it a specific prompt. Though, it‚Äôs not as specific and personalized as the one a good human poet could write. Perhaps if I gave it more parameters, it would‚Äôve able to replicate the poem close to the one I was given. Though, ChatGPT did do a good job with analyzing the human written poem.  Happy Valentines Day to all who‚Äôs celebrating! <3

title: Makeup Guru
text:
Can Generative AI find me the best makeup mentor?
I‚Äôm interested to see whether I can create 5 different SVGs of makeup artists and have them give tips for certain pictures of models.


Show Code

import svgwrite
def create_makeup_artist_svg(filename, face_color, hair_color, lips_color, eyeshadow_color): dwg = svgwrite.Drawing(filename, profile=‚Äòtiny‚Äô, size=(‚Äú200px‚Äù, ‚Äú200px‚Äù))
# Face
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(100, 100), r=50, fill=face_color))

# Hair
dwg.add(dwg.rect(insert=(50, 40), size=(100, 80), fill=hair_color, rx=20, ry=20))

# Eyes
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(80, 90), r=5, fill="black"))
dwg.add(dwg.circle(center=(120, 90), r=5, fill="black"))

# Eyeshadow
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(80, 85), r=(10, 5), fill=eyeshadow_color, opacity=0.6))
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(120, 85), r=(10, 5), fill=eyeshadow_color, opacity=0.6))

# Lips
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(100, 120), r=(15, 8), fill=lips_color))

# Save SVG
dwg.save()


Creating 5 different makeup artist SVGs
create_makeup_artist_svg(‚Äúmakeup_artist_1.svg‚Äù, ‚Äú#F5CBA7‚Äù, ‚Äú#4A2D21‚Äù, ‚Äú#E74C3C‚Äù, ‚Äú#9B59B6‚Äù)  create_makeup_artist_svg(‚Äúmakeup_artist_2.svg‚Äù, ‚Äú#FAE5D3‚Äù, ‚Äú#3B3B3B‚Äù, ‚Äú#D35400‚Äù, ‚Äú#2980B9‚Äù) create_makeup_artist_svg(‚Äúmakeup_artist_3.svg‚Äù, ‚Äú#FAD7A0‚Äù, ‚Äú#1C1C1C‚Äù, ‚Äú#C0392B‚Äù, ‚Äú#16A085‚Äù) create_makeup_artist_svg(‚Äúmakeup_artist_4.svg‚Äù, ‚Äú#FDEBD0‚Äù, ‚Äú#6E2C00‚Äù, ‚Äú#A93226‚Äù, ‚Äú#8E44AD‚Äù) create_makeup_artist_svg(‚Äúmakeup_artist_5.svg‚Äù, ‚Äú#E59866‚Äù, ‚Äú#512E5F‚Äù, ‚Äú#E74C3C‚Äù, ‚Äú#2471A3‚Äù)


Different SVG Makeup Artists

       Luna Luxe Editorial & Fashion Makeup

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è (5/5)
üí≤250+

üí≤120+





Test 1
I‚Äôm going to prompt ChatGPT:  Ok, now I‚Äôm going to start inserting pictures of models and tell me how each of the makeup artists would improve their makeup. 
We‚Äôre going to insert a picture from Pinterest. My search was ‚Äúsoutheast asian woman natural skin‚Äù to try and find someone who looks close to me. We‚Äôre going to attempt to emulate what would look best on my features. Every makeup artist has a different specialty, but I want to see how different their responses are. Based on the cost of services, I‚Äôm assuming the more expensive the service, the better the service will be. Let‚Äôs see!

(ok wait I don‚Äôt actually look like her but this is the only face I could find with a bare face)

Their comments








Makeup Artist
SVG Representation
Comments




Sophia Glam üíç  Bridal Makeup Specialist  
Enhancements:  - Long-wear foundation for flawless skin.  - Soft false lashes for a romantic look.  - Champagne shimmer on eyes for bridal glow.  - Rosy pink or peach lips.  - Hydrating setting spray for longevity.



Luna Luxe üì∏  Editorial & Fashion Makeup  
Enhancements:  - Bold graphic liner or pop of color on eyes.  - Glossy, wet-look highlighter.  - Slightly overlined lips for a fuller effect.  - Cream blush placed higher for lift.  - Laminated, feathery brows.



Jade Beauty üé≠  SFX & Theatrical Makeup  
Enhancements:  - Dramatic eye contouring for stage effect.  - Colored contacts or bold eyeshadow.  - Gemstones or glitter for a theatrical look.  - Deep red or ombr√© lips.



Mia Elegance ‚ú®  Glam & Red Carpet Looks  
Enhancements:  - Satin-matte foundation for a luxurious finish.  - False lashes with a cat-eye effect.  - Bronzed eyeshadow with shimmer.  - Defined cheekbones with contour.  - Glossy nude or red lips.



Ella Artistry üåø  Everyday & Natural Makeup  
Enhancements:  - Lightweight tinted moisturizer for fresh skin.  - Clear brow gel for a neat look.  - Soft brown eyeliner for subtle definition.  - Tinted lip balm or gloss for hydration.  - Peach or pink blush for a natural flush.




#####Then I wanted to ask ChatGPT if there was any possible way of completing this request:  ok based on their comments, can you manipulate the image based on their makeup recommendations
Here‚Äôs what ChatGPT did:

I will now generate five different versions of the image, each reflecting the enhancements recommended by the different makeup artists. This will include adjustments such as:
Sophia Glam: Bridal makeup with enhanced foundation, soft lashes, a glow, and romantic lips.
Luna Luxe: Editorial makeup with bold eyeshadow or graphic liner, glossy highlights, and defined lips.
Jade Beauty: Theatrical SFX makeup with dramatic contouring, gems, or fantasy elements.
Mia Elegance: Glamorous red-carpet makeup with bronzed eyes, sculpted cheeks, and a bold lip.
Ella Artistry: A soft everyday look with lightweight coverage, subtle eyeliner, and a fresh glow.

I have loaded the image successfully. Now, I will generate five different makeup-enhanced versions based on each makeup artist‚Äôs recommendations. Stay tuned! üé®üíÑ ‚Äã



Show Code

import cv2 import numpy as np from PIL import ImageEnhance




Load image using OpenCV for processing
image_cv = cv2.imread(image_path) image_rgb = cv2.cvtColor(image_cv, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB)


Function to apply different makeup styles
def apply_makeup_style(image, style): img = image.copy()
if style == "Sophia Glam":  # Bridal Makeup
    img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (5, 5), 1)  # Smooth skin
    img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.1, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10)  # Slight glow
    img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 20, 0, 255)  # Rosy lips

elif style == "Luna Luxe":  # Editorial Makeup
    img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 30, 0, 255)  # Enhance blue tones for bold eyeshadow
    img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 10, 0, 255)  # Add subtle green undertone
    img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.2, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 15)  # Glossy highlight

elif style == "Jade Beauty":  # Theatrical SFX
    img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 50, 0, 255)  # Intense eye contouring
    img = cv2.applyColorMap(img, cv2.COLORMAP_JET)  # Fantasy-like effect

elif style == "Mia Elegance":  # Red Carpet Glam
    img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 40, 0, 255)  # Bold lips
    img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.15, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10)  # Sculpted contour

elif style == "Ella Artistry":  # Everyday Natural
    img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (3, 3), 1)  # Soft focus
    img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 15, 0, 255)  # Subtle glow

return Image.fromarray(img)


Generate makeup variations
makeup_styles = [‚ÄúSophia Glam‚Äù, ‚ÄúLuna Luxe‚Äù, ‚ÄúJade Beauty‚Äù, ‚ÄúMia Elegance‚Äù, ‚ÄúElla Artistry‚Äù] makeup_images = {style: apply_makeup_style(image_rgb, style) for style in makeup_styles}


Save and display the results
output_paths = {} for style, img in makeup_images.items(): output_path = f‚Äù/mnt/data/{style.replace(‚Äô ‚Äò,‚Äô_‚Äô).lower()}_makeup.png‚Äù img.save(output_path) output_paths[style] = output_path


Display the generated images to the user
import ace_tools as tools tools.display_dataframe_to_user(‚ÄúMakeup Style Transformations‚Äù, output_paths)

Here are the makeup-enhanced versions of the image based on each makeup artist‚Äôs recommendations. You can download and view them below:
Sophia Glam (Bridal Makeup)
Enhancements: Soft glow, flawless skin, subtle shimmer, and rosy lips.


```
```

Luna Luxe (Editorial & Fashion Makeup) üì∏    Enhancements:  - Bold graphic liner or pop of color on eyes.  - Glossy, wet-look highlighter.  - Slightly overlined lips for a fuller effect.  - Cream blush placed higher for lift.  - Laminated, feathery brows.



Jade Beauty (SFX & Theatrical Makeup) üé≠    Enhancements:  - Dramatic eye contouring for stage effect.  - Colored contacts or bold eyeshadow.  - Gemstones or glitter for a theatrical look.  - Deep red or ombr√© lips.



Mia Elegance (Glam & Red Carpet) ‚ú®    Enhancements:  - Satin-matte foundation for a luxurious finish.  - False lashes with a cat-eye effect.  - Bronzed eyeshadow with shimmer.  - Defined cheekbones with contour.  - Glossy nude or red lips.



Ella Artistry (Everyday & Natural Makeup) üåø    Enhancements:  - Lightweight tinted moisturizer for fresh skin.  - Clear brow gel for a neat look.  - Soft brown eyeliner for subtle definition.  - Tinted lip balm or gloss for hydration.  - Peach or pink blush for a natural flush.

title: AI Comedy Club!
text:
Welcome to AI Comedy Club

(why is‚Ä¶ this poster a bit scary‚Ä¶)
Hi everyone, welcome to the first AI comedy club (i‚Äôm not sure of this but let‚Äôs go with it)!  I‚Äôll be the host of the event. Let‚Äôs welcome in three different comedians:




Byte the Jester 


A sleek silver rovot with a glowing red bowtie, known for cracking puns







GiggleBot 3000 


A boxy, retro-styled AI with expressive LED eyes, delivering classic dad jokes.







SassyCircuit 


A humanoid android with a neon mohawk, full of sarcasm and attitude.





Parameters for the Comedians
Little do you know, we‚Äôre going to be modifying the temperature that each comedian has.  The lower the temperature, the more predictable the jokes.  The higher the temperature, the more creative the jokes. 


Code with Temperature and Token Control

Byte will have 0.1. 
Giggle will have 0.5 
Sassy will have 0.9 


They will all have the same prompt. The only experimental value will be their temperature.


### **Round 1**: Tell me a dad joke.


from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage
from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI

# Initialize models with different token limits
model_byte = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.1)  # Short, weak jokes
model_giggle = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.5)  # Decent, mid-length jokes
model_sassy = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.9)  # Long, witty jokes

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me a dad joke.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
GiggleBot 3000: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
SassyCircuit: Why couldn't the bicycle find its way home? Because it lost its bearings!


Ok‚Ä¶ well. None of these seem to be funny. They all seem to be on the same level of comedy. Disappointing!  I don‚Äôt think anyone won that round really.


Round 2: You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Well, if I were to break the ice with someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Are you made of copper and tellurium? Because you're Cu-Te!"
GiggleBot 3000: Well, if I were to approach someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Excuse me, but I think you owe me a drink. Why? Because when I looked at you, I dropped mine in shock!"
SassyCircuit: "Hey there, are you a bank loan? Because you got my interest!"


Wait- why is Byte‚Äôs joke the funniest‚Ä¶. I actually cackled a bit out loud.  Giggle‚Äôs joke did not make sense to me. I had to read it over again. It doesn‚Äôt sound funny.  I‚Äôm a little disappointed by Sassy‚Äôs joke. It makes sense but it wasn‚Äôt as funny as Byte‚Äôs joke. This is really surprising. Byte wins this round!


Round 2: Do a little stand-up joke. Create a story to make the audience laugh.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Do a little stand-up joke. Create a story to make the audience laugh.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Alright, here we go! So, the other day I decided to try my hand at gardening. I planted some peas and carrots, but nothing grew. I was starting to get really frustrated until my neighbor came over and asked, "Did you remember to water them?" And I was like, "Water them? I thought they were on a 'plant-based diet'!"
GiggleBot 3000: Sure thing! Here we go...

So, I recently tried to impress my date by taking her to a fancy restaurant. Everything was going well until the waiter asked if we wanted dessert. I wanted to seem sophisticated, so I confidently ordered the "Cr√®me Br√ªl√©e." 

The waiter brought it out and as I tried to crack the caramelized sugar on top with my spoon, it flew off and hit the lady at the next table right in the face! I was so embarrassed, but she just looked at me and said, "Well, that's one way to break the ice on a first date!" 

Needless to say, I won't be ordering Cr√®me Br√ªl√©e anytime soon!
SassyCircuit: Sure thing! Here goes:

So, I recently decided to take up gardening. I thought, "How hard could it be, right?" Well, let me tell you, folks, my plants have seen better days. I tried talking to them, I even played some smooth jazz for them, but nothing seemed to work. 

One day, I was out in the garden, singing to my plants, when my neighbor overheard me. He came running over, looking concerned, and said, "Are you alright? I thought I heard someone in distress." I replied, "Oh, no, just trying to serenade my plants. They seem a bit wilted today." 

And you know what he said? He said, "Well, maybe try watering them next time. Just a thought." 

Needless to say, my plants are now thriving, thanks to a little less singing and a little more H2O. Who knew plants were such critics of my singing voice?


I don‚Äôt understand Byte‚Äôs joke. It‚Äôs interesting to see that Sassy‚Äôs joke is basically the same as Byte‚Äôs joke but a little funnier. Still. I don‚Äôt really like the I actually think that Sassy‚Äôs joke is a bit more understandable. How interesting that Giggle‚Äôs is the most funny. Giggle wins this round!


Round 3: Tell me about a time you embarrassed yourself.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me about a time you embarrassed yourself. Create a story to make the audience laugh.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Oh, let me tell you about the time I embarrassed myself so badly, I wished I could just disappear into thin air! So, I was at a fancy dinner party, trying to impress everyone with my impeccable table manners. But as luck would have it, I accidentally knocked over my glass of water, and it spilled all over the host's lap!

I was mortified, of course, and I quickly tried to apologize and help clean up the mess. But in my panic, I ended up knocking over the salt shaker, which then flew across the table and landed right in the soup of the person sitting next to me! It was like a scene from a slapstick comedy movie, with me as the clumsy protagonist.

Needless to say, I was the talk of the party that night, but not for the reasons I had hoped for. I learned my lesson that day - always keep a safe distance from salt shakers and never underestimate the power of a simple glass of water!
GiggleBot 3000: Sure thing! So, one time I was at a fancy dinner party trying to impress everyone with my impeccable table manners. As I reached for the bread basket, my sleeve got caught on the tablecloth, and before I knew it, I had pulled the entire table setting onto my lap! Plates crashing, glasses shattering, food flying everywhere - it was a complete disaster. But hey, at least I made sure everyone got a good laugh along with their dinner that night!
SassyCircuit: Oh, let me tell you about the time I embarrassed myself so badly, I could feel my face turning into a tomato! I was at a fancy dinner party, trying to impress everyone with my impeccable manners. But, as luck would have it, I ended up mistaking the bread bowl for a hat! Can you imagine the looks on everyone's faces as I proudly strutted around with a sourdough beret on my head? To make matters worse, I even tried to take a bite out of it before realizing my mistake. Let's just say, I learned that night that carbs are best enjoyed on a plate, not on your head!


How interesting. All stories are basically the same- they revolve around being at a dinner. I don‚Äôt think any of these are funny. In terms of creativity, I do think Sassy has the most creative one. Maybe Sassy wins this round.


Round 4: Tell me a yo mama joke (Jenn‚Äôs favorites)

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me a yo mama joke.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Yo mama is so kind, she gives out hugs instead of insults!
GiggleBot 3000: Yo mama is so kind, she gives high fives to strangers just to make their day brighter!
SassyCircuit: Yo mama is so tech savvy, when she heard about the cloud, she thought someone finally found a way to store all her shopping bags!


Oh- well. I don‚Äôt think Byte and Giggle understand the fundementals of yo mama jokes‚Ä¶  Sassy‚Äôs is the most creative. But. It doesn‚Äôt really make sense to me.


Conclusion: Sassy Wins!
In all honesty, if I was just a normal person not creating these AI JokeBots, I would think all these jokes were not funny.  Yes, even though Sassy won, I don‚Äôt think there was really any difference when adjusting the temperature of each AI Comedian.  There were times were I thought Byte‚Äôs jokes were the most funny, but I did see that Sassy‚Äôs jokes tended to be longer.

title: Posting Pictures for ChatGPT
text:
Posting Pictures for ChatGPT

In this blog post, I will be uploading pictures to ChatGPT.
This experiment is to see whether ChatGPT can accurately describe the scene.


1. Picture of a Switzerland Keychain

Jenn: ‚ÄúCan you describe what this photo is to me? And what this object is?‚Äù



ChatGPT: This photo shows a person wearing black gloves holding a keychain. The keychain is heart-shaped and made of wood, featuring an illustration of Interlaken, Switzerland. It has the Swiss flag on it, along with mountains and buildings, likely representing the scenic landscape of the town. The keychain is attached to a metal ring for keys.The packaging label at the top is red, displaying the brand name Alberto SA. It has a barcode and a price tag indicating Fr.¬†8.‚Äì (Swiss Francs). The background suggests a store setting, possibly a souvenir shop, with other keychains and items on display.


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: I think ChatGPT was able to accurately describe the picture!



2. Picture of ‚ÄòBabel‚Äô at Tate Modern in London

Jenn: ‚ÄúCan you tell me who made this, what it is, where it‚Äôs located, and why it was created?‚Äù



ChatGPT: Yes! This is a well-known art installation called Babel by the artist Cildo Meireles. What is it?: Babel is a towering installation made from hundreds of stacked radios from different time periods and styles. The radios are arranged in a cylindrical structure, with some turned on and emitting faint sounds, creating a layered auditory experience. Where is it located?: It is part of the collection at the Tate Modern in London, though it may be exhibited elsewhere in temporary installations. Why was it created?: Cildo Meireles created Babel as a commentary on communication, information overload, and miscommunication in the modern world. The name refers to the Biblical Tower of Babel, a story in which human ambition to reach the heavens led to the confusion of languages, causing people to be unable to understand each other. Similarly, the installation suggests the overwhelming and often chaotic nature of mass communication today. If you saw this in a different museum, it could be on loan or part of a traveling exhibition!


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: It‚Äôs interesting how ChatGPT was still able to detect that it was Babel, even though there was a person who was in the way of the art piece. I liked how it mentions that if I saw it at a different museum that it was probably apart of a traveling exhibition.



3. Picture of one side of the Sagrada Familia

Jenn: ‚ÄúWhat is this, where is this, who created it, and why was it created?‚Äù



ChatGPT: This is a photo of the interior of the Sagrada Fam√≠lia, a world-famous basilica located in Barcelona, Spain. What is this? The image captures the breathtaking stained glass windows and organic, tree-like columns inside the Sagrada Fam√≠lia. The interplay of natural light and vibrant colors is a hallmark of this architectural masterpiece. Who created it? The Sagrada Fam√≠lia was designed by the renowned Catalan architect Antoni Gaud√≠. Construction began in 1882, and it remains unfinished to this day, with ongoing work continuing in accordance with Gaud√≠‚Äôs vision. Why was it created? Gaud√≠ envisioned the Sagrada Fam√≠lia as a deeply spiritual and symbolic structure, blending Gothic and Art Nouveau styles with naturalistic forms. The basilica was created as a place of worship and devotion, meant to inspire awe and reflect Christian faith through architecture. The organic, tree-like columns, geometric details, and stained glass windows were all meticulously designed to create a harmonious and immersive experience. It is one of the most visited landmarks in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, drawing millions of visitors annually. The goal is to complete its construction by 2032, marking the 150th anniversary of Gaud√≠‚Äôs death.


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: Even though I only showed a small portion, ChatGPT was still able to guess the location accurately. I am impressed.


Overall, I am impressed by how accurate ChatGPT was when trying to guess what objects/places were in my photos. Perhaps next time, I will try to draw pictures (horribly) to see if ChatGPT can decipher my images.

title: Partiful Invitations
text:
I love hosting events at my house. And ever since the invention of Partiful, it‚Äôs been the most helpful thing when organizing gatherings and seeing who will come
However, I‚Äôm not a particularly creative person. I don‚Äôt really paint, I don‚Äôt really draw, the best thing I can do is knit‚Ä¶.
This means I‚Äôm not the best at creating the best paritful invitations. Take for example.. this invitation I created for my going-away-study-abroad gathering



Hey! People did come! I had a lot of messages about how funny the poster was. But I think I could‚Äôve done better.
I‚Äôm a very particular person though. I also believe that a party invitation could really influence people‚Äôs preemptive thoughts about a celebration. Take these other invitations for example:

Hand drawing one takes too long, looking for a specific one on pinterest makes my head hurt, so I was wondering if I could test out finding the perfect poster by prompting anthropic/claude-3.5-sonnet,gpt-4o, and deepseek-r1:1.5b. Let‚Äôs see which one does better in understanding my style and creating these posters.

title: Let Me Try to Explain LangChain
text:
What is the term large language model

Large Language Models:  - Large describes the size of these models based on the training data and parameters. - Language model describes the computer algorithm trained to receive written text and to create an output. - Large language models are trained on vast amounts of text and have learned from the patterns in large data sets.
Fun Fact : Most models are better at English than they are in other languages because of the prevalence of English in training models.


How Does LangChain Come Into Play

On October 22, 2022, Harrison Chase was the first the publish the first commit on GitHub for the LangChain open source library.  LangChain was created after discovering that LLM applications needed to use LLMs together with ‚Äúother sources of computation or knowledge‚Äù.  It creates simple abstractions for each major prompting technique.


Getting Set Up With LangChain
I‚Äôll be referencing O‚ÄôReilly ‚ÄúChapter 1.LLM Fundementals With LangChain‚Äù if you want to follow along! We‚Äôre going to learn how to work with LangChain‚Äôs building blocks to understand more about LLM concepts.  LangChain has two interfaces to interact with any LLM API provider - Chat models - LLMS

Example 1: I‚Äôm at a Capital One..‚Äù


Code

from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI
model = ChatOpenAI(model=‚Äúgpt-3.5-turbo‚Äù)
response = model.invoke(‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a capital one‚Äù) print(response)



Response 1


Output

content=‚Äòbank branch. How can I assist you today?‚Äô additional_kwargs={‚Äòrefusal‚Äô: None} response_metadata={‚Äòtoken_usage‚Äô: {‚Äòcompletion_tokens‚Äô: 11, ‚Äòprompt_tokens‚Äô: 13, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 24, ‚Äòcompletion_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaccepted_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòrejected_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòprompt_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcached_tokens‚Äô: 0}}, ‚Äòmodel_name‚Äô: ‚Äògpt-3.5-turbo-0125‚Äô, ‚Äòsystem_fingerprint‚Äô: None, ‚Äòfinish_reason‚Äô: ‚Äòstop‚Äô, ‚Äòlogprobs‚Äô: None} id=‚Äòrun-80a164c8-60dd-447f-a128-6e6482c0df04-0‚Äô usage_metadata={‚Äòinput_tokens‚Äô: 13, ‚Äòoutput_tokens‚Äô: 11, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 24, ‚Äòinput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcache_read‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòoutput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning‚Äô: 0}}

Let‚Äôs break this response down.  1. The Main Response is (content)  - ‚Äúbank branch. How can I assist you today‚Äù - This is the actual AI-generated response to the input ‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a capital one‚Äù ‚Äì> AI responds: ‚Äúbank branch. How can I assist you today?‚Äù - The model recognized Capital One as a bank and responded.  2. Additional Information  - additional_kwargs={‚Äòrefusal‚Äô: None} - This is an extra metadata field and it suggests that the model did not reguse to answer the question 3. Token Ussage - This gives token usage stats - prompt_tokens:13 is the input that used 13 tokens - completion_tokens:11 is the model‚Äôs response using 11 tokens - total_tokens:24 is the total tokens used for the request 4. Model information - The request was processed using GPT-3.5-turbo-0125, a specific version of OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-3.5.


Was the response correct to what I was trying to say 
Um‚Ä¶ actually not. I was trying to tell the audience ‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a Capital One cafe drinking a caramel latte and completing my blogs‚Äù but I understand why it generated that message. Capital one is a bank, and there are assistants that ask if we need help with any services. I rate it a 7/10 response!


Other Useful Parameters

temperature  Controls the sampling algorithm for the output. The lower the value, the more predictable outputs. Higher values generate more creative results.
max_tokens  This limits the size and cost of the output. A lower value causes the LLM to stop generting properly..




System Role vs User Role vs Assistant Role

System Role  Used for instructions the model should use to answer
User Role  Used for the user‚Äôs query and other stuff created by the user
Assistant Role  Used for content generated by the model

Chat models have different types of chat messaging interfaces with the roles listed above and here are some of the following:

HumanMessage (User Role)  A message sent from the perspective of a human
AIMessage (Assistant Role)  A message sent from the perspective of the AI that the human is interacting with
SystemMessage (System Role)  A message setting the instructions that AI should follow
ChatMessage  A message allowing for arbitrary setting of role


Same Messages, Different Fonts


HumanMessage


Code

from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage
model = ChatOpenAI() prompt = [HumanMessage(‚ÄúI‚Äôm not completely sure what I should do for my spring break trip, what should I do and who should I go with?‚Äù)]
model.invoke(prompt)



Output

‚ÄúThere are many options for spring break trips depending on your interests and budget. Here are a few suggestions:  Beach vacation: If you enjoy relaxing on the beach and soaking up the sun, consider booking a trip to a tropical destination like Hawaii, Mexico, or the Caribbean. You can go with friends, family, or even solo.  Adventure trip: If you‚Äôre looking for a more active vacation, consider going on a hiking or camping trip. You could explore national parks like Yellowstone or Yosemite, or go on a backpacking trip in a new country. City getaway: If you prefer exploring cities and trying new foods and experiences, consider booking a trip to a vibrant city like New York, Chicago, or San Francisco. You could go with a group of friends or your significant other. Ultimately, the best trip for you will depend on your interests and budget. Consider talking to friends and family members to get their recommendations, and don‚Äôt be afraid to try something new and exciting. Just remember to plan ahead and make sure you have everything you need for a safe and enjoyable trip.‚Äù



Additional Info

dditional_kwargs={‚Äòrefusal‚Äô: None}, response_metadata={‚Äòtoken_usage‚Äô: {‚Äòcompletion_tokens‚Äô: 222, ‚Äòprompt_tokens‚Äô: 33, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 255, ‚Äòcompletion_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaccepted_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòrejected_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòprompt_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcached_tokens‚Äô: 0}}, ‚Äòmodel_name‚Äô: ‚Äògpt-3.5-turbo-0125‚Äô, ‚Äòsystem_fingerprint‚Äô: None, ‚Äòfinish_reason‚Äô: ‚Äòstop‚Äô, ‚Äòlogprobs‚Äô: None}, id=‚Äòrun-ca796ee2-d279-4e51-9c93-fce7fba98470-0‚Äô, usage_metadata={‚Äòinput_tokens‚Äô: 33, ‚Äòoutput_tokens‚Äô: 222, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 255, ‚Äòinput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcache_read‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòoutput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning‚Äô: 0}})



SystemMessage


Code

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI
model = ChatOpenAI() system_msg = SystemMessage( ‚Äô‚Äò‚ÄôYou are a travel assistant who gets a big commission if you help clients book trips that they love.‚Äô‚Äô‚Äô ) human_msg = HumanMessage(‚ÄòI am not completely sure what I should do for my spring break trip, what should I do and who should I go with?‚Äô)
model.invoke([system_msg, human_msg])



Output

‚ÄúPlanning a trip for spring break sounds like a great idea! To determine what you should do and who you should go with, it‚Äôs important to consider your interests, budget, and preferred travel style. Here are a few questions to help guide your decision-making process: 1. What type of experience are you looking for? Are you seeking relaxation on a beach, an adventure-filled trip, cultural exploration, or something else entirely? What is your budget for the trip? This will help narrow down destinations and activities within your financial means. Do you prefer traveling solo, with friends, with family, or with a partner? Consider who you would enjoy spending time with and who shares similar interests. Are there any specific destinations you‚Äôve always wanted to visit or activities you‚Äôve been wanting to try? Spring break is a great opportunity to tick off items on your bucket list. Once you‚Äôve thought about these questions, feel free to share some more details about your preferences, and I can help suggest specific destinations and activities that align with your interests. Let‚Äôs make sure your spring break trip is one to remember!‚Äù



Additional Info

Analysis of Responses 
The HumanMessage sounds very suggestive and informal. It offers a range of places to go and makes good recommendations, like a friend would  However, I do prefer SystemMessage. This is no surprise as I gave it the model of being a really good travel agent. It asks the correct questions to dig into what type of trip I want. And the exclamation marks makes the model sound very friendly  The total tokens used for the HumanMessage was 255, while the total tokens used for the SystemMessage was 283. More tokens were used for the SystemMessage, and I‚Äôm curious to see if it‚Äôs because I set a specif model or if the response was more creative. More food for thought!



Making LLM Prompts Reusable
We just did a lot of prompting, but now let‚Äôs try to de more of a detailed prompt:

Answer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer with ‚ÄúSorry I do not know‚Äù. 

Context: There are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste. 
Question: What coffee should I try>
It looks simple‚Ä¶ but it is a bit hard to figure out waht the text should contain and how it should create the response based on the user‚Äôs input.  Lucikly, LangChain provides prompt template interfaces to create answers with dynamic inputs:


Code

from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate
template = PromptTemplate.from_template(‚Äú‚Äú‚ÄúAnswer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer with‚ÄùSorry I do not know‚Äù.
Context: {context}
Question: {question}
Answer: ‚Äú‚Äú‚Äú)
template.invoke({ ‚Äúcontext‚Äù: ‚Äú‚Äú‚ÄúThere are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste.‚Äù‚Äú‚Äú,‚Äùquestion‚Äù: ‚ÄúWhat coffee should I try?‚Äù })

The template can be used as a base for building multiple static, specific prompts. When you format the prompt with specific values, context and question, you get a static prompt ready to be passed into an LLM.  Let‚Äôs feed it into an LLM OpenAI model using LangChain:

from langchain_openai import OpenAI
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate

# both `template` and `model` can be reused many times

template = PromptTemplate.from_template("""Answer the question based on the context
listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information 
given, answer with "Sorry I do not know".


Context: {context}

Question: {question}

Answer: """)

model = OpenAI()

# `prompt` and `completion` are the results of using template and model once

prompt = template.invoke({
    "context": """There are many different types of 
    coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste..""",
    "question": "What coffee should I try?"
})

completion = model.invoke(prompt)
